summary: Adjust macos build documentation
author: mh+mozilla@glandium.org
text:
Created attachment 9206543
Bug 1696086 - Adjust macos build documentation.

The current instructions tell to install brew, Xcode, and Mercurial,
then go on to use the bootstrap script.

However, the bootstrap script will take care of those three steps on its
own (except Mercurial, where it will only tell to run pip3 install
Mercurial, until future improvements just make it do it on its own).

On a fresh macOS install, though, python3 is not actually installed
(although the binary exists), but running a python3 command will launch
an installer. Warn about that.

author: rob@robwu.nl
text:
I wanted to look up the page that described the `dev-doc-needed` process, but was surprisingly not able to find it any more. It is at https://github.com/mdn/archived-content/blob/main/files/en-us/mozilla/developer_guide/getting_documentation_updated/index.html

There are many more articles under `developer_guide`: 
https://github.com/mdn/archived-content/tree/main/files/en-us/mozilla/developer_guide

Only a few of the entries are listed at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1w5WIy_X4vbIWrxH4pC8geqWKgpinj31I9ePwvBcZ9vQ/edit

Although some of the `developer_guide` documentation has moved already, it seems that there haven't been a systematic evaluation of whether the articles under `developer_guide` should be kept or removed. Instead of waiting for people to discover missing documentation (e.g. as happened in bug 1727117), please list all entries and check if they need to be migrated.

summary: Update "Triage for Bugzilla"
author: glob@mozilla.com
text:
At the end of 2020 the following email updated the definition of triage.  https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/bug-mgmt/policies/triage-bugzilla.html needs to be updated to match:

--

Hello Triage Owners and Release Managers,

tl;dr

This is a continuation of bringing consistency to Firefox bug triage processes and using them to help improve Firefox release quality. We’ll clarify expectations around Priority based on Severity and ensure triage queues don’t miss either field being unset.
The bugzilla changes for automatic setting of fields and bug bot nudges will start to take effect some time early/mid January so expect some more bugmail then.

**Same as before:**

* During triage, review the ‘bug type’ also and edit it, if needed. The current default type is ‘Defect’. Use [this](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/bug-mgmt/guides/bug-types.html) as a guide.
* For bug type of defects, set bug severity as an indicator of ‘how bad is this issue for the user?’. Use [this](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/bug-mgmt/guides/severity.html) as a guide.
* Anyone in the editbugs group has the ability to set the severity.

**New changes requiring action from you:**

* _Note: For bugs filed or reproduced by QA, the QA team will be setting the bug severity._
* Change your bug triage queries to check for an unset severity OR priority as the criteria. This is so that your triage does not miss bugs that have severity set by QA or another user from the editbugs group. You can add your component(s) to [this query](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/query.cgi?chfield=[Bug%20creation]&chfieldfrom=-4y&classification=Components&f1=priority&f2=bug_severity&j_top=OR&list_id=15485204&o1=equals&o2=equals&query_format=advanced&resolution=---&v1=--&v2=--) to get the untriaged bugs opened within the last 4 years (please edit the timeline as desired).
* Bugzilla will require a comment regarding rationale for any changes to bug severity.
* Mark the most severe issues as S1 in Bugzilla so they are accurately highlighted and get the right eyes on them.
* If you are a triage owner, please find assignees for all S1 bugs within 2 business days.

**Background and Details**

As you might remember from earlier this year, we made major changes to our definition of a ‘triaged’ bug to directly correspond to a severity being set. As part of this, we changed the default severity value from ‘Normal’ to ‘--’. This was done so we can use queries and filters on bug severity fields to identify and fix the most critical issues within the current release cycle, to maintain and improve our release quality.

When this change was proposed, we asked triage owners to modify their triage queries to search for bugs that had an empty severity field. However, in some cases, bugs are filed by QA who are in a good position to gauge the severity of the bug from a user’s perspective. Therefore, for QA-filed bugs, QA should be setting the bug severity, which can, if needed, be modified by the triage owner or bug assignee at a later time. Therefore, the triage owners should use severity-unset OR priority-unset as the triage criteria, [this query](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/query.cgi?chfield=[Bug%20creation]&chfieldfrom=-4y&classification=Components&f1=priority&f2=bug_severity&j_top=OR&list_id=15485204&o1=equals&o2=equals&query_format=advanced&resolution=---&v1=--&v2=--) can be used as the base for the desired component. We understand that this requires manual changes and is not the most convenient solution. In the future, we will try to provide automated triage query format and/or nag emails to ease this.

[Here](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/bug-mgmt/guides/severity.html) are more details about severity levels and some examples of different severity level scenarios.

author: lucas.werkmeister@web.de
text:
The instructions at https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/setup/linux_build.html ([archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20220729143853/https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/setup/linux_build.html)), at the end of step 2 “Bootstrap a copy of the Firefox source code”, advise users to “Cleanup” by removing the `bootstrap.py` script. However, `bootstrap.py` already cleans up after itself:

    Clone complete.                                                          
    If you need to run the tooling bootstrapping again, then consider running './mach bootstrap' instead.                                              
    Unless you are going to have more local copies of Firefox source code, this 'bootstrap.py' file is no longer needed and can be deleted. Clean up the bootstrap.py file? (Y/n)

If `bootstrap.py` still exists, it’s because the user explicitly wanted it so. So I think this section of the documentation can simply be removed.

summary: Document the reasons to maintain our own string classes over the std ones
author: krosylight@mozilla.com
text:
I can't find any mention about the reasons in coding style related docs:

* https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/code-quality/coding-style/using_cxx_in_firefox_code.html
* https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/xpcom/stringguide.html
* https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/code-quality/coding-style/coding_style_cpp.html

summary: Document the reasons to maintain our own string classes over the std ones
author: krosylight@mozilla.com
text: Hi Bobby, is this something in your area?

summary: Document the reasons to maintain our own string classes over the std ones
author: nika@thelayzells.com
text:
There are many different reasons why we have our own string types, many of which are historical, but also many which apply today. Here's a definitely-incomplete list of small things in no particular order:

* nsTString supports a literal string optimization, which allows them to store and pass around a literal string without copying it onto the heap. 
* nsTString has bindings to Rust, which allows us to use this type in FFI interfaces with our rust code, such as for XPCOM interfaces.
* nsTString uses reference-counted COW buffers to store the string data, which means that when a nsTString is copied, it does not need to copy the underlying string value, and can instead increment the underlying reference count.
  * This used to be especially important pre-c++11 as there were no move semantics, and copying a string buffer around would be very inefficient.
  * For modern code this may be less of a win, but could definitely be an issue if we were to do a naive conversion.
  * This also makes the implicit copy constructor less of a footgun.
* nsTString has an "auto" variant which can be passed around like a nsTString due to class semantics, but stores string data on the stack to prevent unnecessary copies.
  * Many std::string implementations also have a small string optimization, however it is generally much smaller than the nsTString type.
* A owned nsTString is safe to relocate in memory without invoking the move constructor.
* std::string provides no memory reporting functionality, and doesn't give the ability to control things like how the backing buffers are allocated. 
  * This means that we could not provide efficient conversions between nsTString and std::string types if we were to adopt it in more places, requiring full string copies at any boundaries.
* We have special optimizations in place to allow nsTString types to avoid copies in some cases when transferring strings into the JS engine or borrowing strings from the JS engine.
  * These depend on the ability to control things like the backing buffer, and probably wouldn't be possible to do with std::string.
* The bulk of our existing code already uses nsTString, meaning that sticking with it helps with consistency across the codebase.
* Support for wide strings (like nsString) is a bit spotty for the stdlib, and std::u16string was only added in c++11.
  * The std::wstring type uses `wchar_t`, which is only 16-bit-wide on Windows, and is a footgun on other platforms.
  * nsTString has special handling to enable it to work with wchar_t APIs on windows, while using char16_t on other platforms.
* Until c++17 added std::string_view, there was no standard type for holding a borrowed substring, meaning that APIs which wanted to take or pass strings had to pass around full std::string copies. nsTSubstring has always had support for being backed by a borrowed reference to part of another string.
* Due to ABI constraints, it is not possible for std::string to change to e.g. become more efficient.
  * Some companies (facebook comes to mind) replace std::string with their own API-compatible implementation for performance reasons (https://github.com/facebook/folly/blob/main/folly/docs/FBString.md). 

I'm sure I missed some other things worth noting.

We do have support for interfacing nsTString with the stdlib types in various places, for example you can convert a `const nsACString&` to a c++17 `std::string_view`, and I expect that over time we may increase our support for that, but I don't see std::string/std::string_view replacing nsTString completely any time soon.

summary: Document the reasons to maintain our own string classes over the std ones
author: bholley@mozilla.com
text: Thanks Nika. At a high level, the trade-off between home-grown versus standard data structures is generally between flexibility and interoperability. Gecko is a big monolithic and performance-sensitive codebase where flexibility is very helpful, and the parts of the C++ ecosystem we work with are heterogeneous enough that we don't experience a lot of interop pressure in practice.

summary: [meta] Improve Firefox Contributor's Quick Reference document
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
Some things we have noticed during this Outreachy cycle:
- Contributors are confused about how to get started even when pointed at the existing set up documentation
  - This seems to be primarily because of network errors causing `hg clone` to fail or get into odd states. It seems like promoting the Mercurial Bundles document is a good idea.
  - There is also concern about the amount of time it takes to read and import all the changesets of mozilla-unified, so we should make a note that this part can take a very long time depending on machine specs.
 - I have also seen confusion about which option to select when running `./mach bootstrap`. We should list the reasons for each one and say something about "most likely you will need the default option".
- Contributors are not sure what the expectations are about messaging potential mentors and may ping folks unnecessarily
  - This is just expectation setting and varies from culture to culture, so laying down explicit guidelines would help get rid of ambiguity for all parties involved
- Contributors are not needinfo'ing mentors on bugs when they have questions
  - Unless mentors are actively watching bugmail for comment notifications, it is very easy to miss assignee comment. We should explicitly encourage the use of the needinfo feature of bugzilla.
  - We should also note that mentors should be actively watching their mentored bugs and set expectations accordingly. This way contributors know that they should get a response in `x` days or something, even if they didn't use the needinfo feature on their comment.
- Contributors are used to Git/GitHub and are unused of how to deal with Mercurial's mental model (or the fact that Firefox is not stored in a git repo)
  - While we have some documentation on this, [mconley's document on how he uses Mercurial for Mozilla code](https://mikeconley.github.io/documents/How_mconley_uses_Mercurial_for_Mozilla_code) seems to resonate well with folks and helps them understand what to do.
   - Should we be promoting `git-cinnabar` usage to these folks? They most likely have a git background to begin with and so this removes one more hurdle. However it adds one more hurdle, one more thing to install, one more README to understand to the process.
  - We should also be **very** explicit about creating one commit per bug (since most folks will be contributing to good-first-bugs that should be solvable within one small commit). Otherwise contributors are going to get into states they do not understand and will have to start using `hg rebase` and `hg histedit` on top of learning Mercurial in the first place. This is most likely (and understandably) overwhelming when trying to get a contribution in.
- Contributors are unsure of how to be assigned bugs to work on
  - Some mentors will require people to leave comments on the bug, while others are okay with anyone submitting patches without prior approval.
  - This will require discussion to help keep things fair in the long run, as both choices have pros and cons. Maybe there's a third (or fourth) better way to handle this situation.
- Contributors seem too quick to dig in and immediately solve the problem
  - It does feel like a bit of a mad dash of "ask to work on bug, solve bug, move on to new bug". We should probably have some wording about slowing down, asking questions, and seeking understanding of what the bug is asking for, how to solve the bug, how to verify the bug has been solved, etc.
- Contributors are asking to ask for help (instead of just asking for help)
   - Again, this is just expectation setting, but something we should clarify so that when people can help with available, instead of waiting around for someone to type up what issue they are running into.
- Contributors don't seem to be lurking or reading the scrollback of the rooms they are joining
  - This is most likely just another culture point, but we should make it clear that there are other people who are likely running into the same issues and asking the same questions. But also it should be worded in a way that doesn't actively disincentivize asking questions. Like it should be a "do your due diligence" kind of thing.
- Contributors are posting screenshots and not utilizing https://paste.mozilla.org
  - Maybe this is just a personal nit and so I could be persuaded either way, but many folks are posting screenshots (or photos of screenshots) which can be hard to read or missing context.
  - It seems like paste.mozilla.org is perfect for this logging situations but maybe having screenshots in the chat is better due to them being more permanent as opposed to a pastebin link.
- Contributors don't know where to find bugs in order to contribute
  - We have https://codetribute.mozilla.org and so we just need to promote this more.
- Contributors are concerned about errors that are not fatal errors
   - For example, there was a case of a Java extension in vscode becoming confused about some of the paths inside of mozilla-central.
   - Another case was a Glean error about setting a metrics feature or something
   - Another one was `Region.sys.mjs` failing to fetch a region.
- Contributors are confused about text editors that appear (vim, nano, etc)
   - Not sure what would be the best way to handle this, maybe just point at other helpful documentation for these editors?
- Contributors are confused on how to add commits and submit patches
   - We have documentation on these subjects, but we'll probably just need to add more details in this case
- Contributors are unsure of how to attach screenshots in comments on bugzilla
   - We just need to explain where to find this as it isn't clear until you've found the "Attach New File" button once
- Contributors on Windows are confused by "warning: Watchman unavailable: "watchman" executable not in PATH ([WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified)"
   - We should specify that this is just a warning and can be safely ignored
- Contributors are unsure of what should happen when you run `./mach build` and `./mach run`
   - Maybe we should include a description of what happens as well as a screenshot of a local build running?
- Contributors do not know what meta bugs are
    - Probably just need a short section explaining what meta bugs are and how they aren't (typically) assigned directly
- Contributors do not know what the `clobber` command is and so are afraid to run it
    - Probably just need a short section explaining what `clobber` does and how it is a non-destructive operation but maybe increase build times if using full builds.
- Contributors are unsure of how to understand the Depends on/Blocks/dependency tree/graph section of a bug
    - Need a section explaining that a bug is most likely ready to be worked on if all the bugs it depends on are resolved/closed
    - I think we also need to call out the "Open" versus "Closed" status of bugs.
- (Outreachy specific) Contributors are unsure what is considered a contribution and how to record it
   - I think we can include this as part of the project descriptions we submit to Outreachy, like "use phabricator links and bugzilla links to show work, bugs that have the Closed status are considered contributions"

summary: Expand tabbrowser documentation to include information on gBrowser
author: hjones@mozilla.com
text:
The current `tabbrowser` documentation is pretty terse, and makes no mention of the relationship between `tabbrowser` and `gBrowser`. It would be valuable to expand on this, especially considering `gBrowser` is referenced [all over the place](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/search?q=gBrowser&path=browser%2F**%2F*&case=true&regexp=false) in Firefox front-end code. Given how frequently people probably come across or use `gBrowser`, it seems like it would be helpful/valuable to surface more meaningful search results when someone searches for `gBrowser` from within Firefox Source Docs.

Some ideas for information we could include:

* The fact that `gBrowser` is a window-global instance of `tabbrowser`
* `gBrowser` is primarily concerned with all things tab related - switching tabs, adding and removing tabs, etc.
  * Bonus points if we are able to document `gBrowser`'s responsibilities more comprehensively, but that seems daunting based on the code (all 6000+ lines of it). Even a pretty high level explanation would be useful
* Some `tabbrowser`, `gBrowser`, and `xul:browser` disambiguation - touch on how these are all related
* What's up with the name `gBrowser`? Where did that come from? What's in a name?

This is all covered by :mconley in [this episode](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cRC7BSrQi88#t=25m32s) of The Joy of Coding. To start it would be enough just to get the information discussed there into source docs.

URL = https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/browser/base/tabbrowser/index.html

summary: Add front end team's Code Review Standards to docs
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
To help Mozilla out with this bug, here's the steps:

1. Comment here on the bug that you want to volunteer to help.
   This will tell others that you're working on the next steps.
2. [Download and build the Firefox source code](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/contributing/contribution_quickref.html)
   - [Here is a more detailed tutorial for getting set up to work on Firefox](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/setup/index.html)
   * If you have any problems, please ask on [Element/Matrix](https://chat.mozilla.org/#/room/#introduction:mozilla.org) in the `#introduction` channel. They're there to help you get started.
4. Start working on this bug.
   - First, run `./mach doc browser/docs`. This will install the necessary dependencies and build only the `browser` section of the docs (there are lot of unnecessary docs that will be built if you run just `./mach doc`!).
      - This operation may take a few minutes!
      - There may be a lot of red/error text about "WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree", you can ignore this for the most part.
   - After running `./mach docs browser/docs`, a browser should appear with the url being localhost:5500. This is the built documentation.
   - Create a new file called "CodeReviewBestPractices.md" under browser/docs/ and add [this Firefox Desktop Front end Code Review Best Practices document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/11W-zo4eVNOtkjVfY86AkHBvybomOrtYWwHD3dxkGZwg/edit) to the newly created file and make sure it is formatted properly (including headings at the correct level).
   - You will also need to add "CodeReviewBestPractices" to the browser/docs/index.rst file to see your changes show up in the built documentation.
   * If you have any problems with this bug, please comment on this bug and set the needinfo flag for me.
5. Build your change with `mach doc` and verify your change by navigating to the newly created doc. Also check your changes for adherence to our style guidelines by using `mach lint`.
6. Submit the patch (including an automated test, if applicable) for review. Mark me as a reviewer so I'll get an email to come look at your code.
   * [How to Submit a Patch](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/contributing/how_to_submit_a_patch.html)
   * **This is when the bug will be assigned to you**.
7. After a series of reviews and changes to your patch, I'll push it to autoland.
   * If there are changes requested, [please read the "To update a submitted patch" section to ensure you don't accidentally create a duplicate revision!](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/contributing/contribution_quickref.html#to-update-a-submitted-patch)
   * Your code will soon be shipping to Firefox users worldwide!

summary: Add section about messaging expectations to the quick reference document
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
We should add a section about messaging expectations when working on good-first-bugs for new contributors. This should probably contain:
- Don't ask to ask, just ask
- Use public facing channels to ask your questions instead of direct messaging folks
  - Added benefit of others getting to learn since we end up answering the same questions when the Outreachy period begins.
  - Added benefit of building confidence of new contributors to ask their questions out in the open
- The expectation that people may not immediately respond to your message
  - But also letting people know when to bump a previous question. Sometimes things get dropped or notifications get lost in the sea of other things!
- Learning to go through recent scrollback in a channel to see if their question has been asked and/or answered already.
  - We don't want to discourage questions but we do want to teach new contributors on how to critically think and search for answers to their questions
- Any other messaging expectations that help new contributors work out in the open.

summary: Add section about Mercurial vs Git in the quick reference document
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
The Mercurial information should not be extensive, we should link back to the Mercurial docs in this case. However, we should also have some section explaining (or linking) the big differences between Mercurial and Git. It's safe to assume new developers will have experience with Git and not Mercurial. 

Maybe this is part of this bug, maybe it's part of a different one but this section also seems like a good time to mention the "one commit per bug" rule of thumb for good-first-bugs. Happy to hear other opinions on this, but good-first-bugs should be solvable in one smaller commit and gives new contributors a chance to practice this pattern. It also helps prevent having to explain how `rebase` or `histedit` work on top of everything else a new contributor has to do to get a good-first-bug to land.

There's also some other questions that could be answered as part of this work:
- Should we be promoting `git-cinnabar` to new folks? More often than not `git-cinnabar` will allow these new contributors to leverage their Git knowledge instead of having to find the equivalent `hg` commands.

summary: Add section explaining how bugs are assigned in quick reference document
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
New contributors are unsure of how bugs are assigned (and we're not entirely consistent on how bugs are given out). We should decide on how to deal with this as it's a difficult problem when the Outreachy contribution period starts. We don't want people hoarding bugs, but we also want people to have enough time to work on bugs before potentially re-assigning the bug. Not sure what "fair" looks like in this case, feels like there is no right answer.

Maybe determining the "fair" process can be a follow up to this and this bug can be as simple as "add section that explains bugs are assigned when a patch is submitted to the bug" for the sake of iteratively improving. Curious to hear other thoughts on this.

summary: Add section about how to work on a good-first-bug to quick reference document
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
This is especially relevant to the Outreachy contribution period. We get a lot of contributors who speed through bugs because they want to make sure they get some amount of contributions in before the period is over. However this means they'll avoid running tests, may introduce antipatterns, and generally not understand the problem they are trying to solve. I don't believe we want to encourage this hasty pattern in new contributors and so we should have a section about some common steps to take when working on a new section of code. This section should probably have some text like:
- Ask questions about the bug and your understanding of it
- How to solve the bug itself
- How to verify a solution fixes the bug
- other relevant pieces for this section.

New contributors tend to stop when they see any kind of error, whether it is relevant, non-fatal, etc. We should add some guidance on how to read errors and how to determine if an error is actually blocking or not. For example we've seen the following cases:

- On Windows, `warning: Watchman unavailable: "watchman" executable not in PATH ([WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified)`

### Proposed addition (all the text below):

## How can I run accessibility tests (a11y-checks)?

The Tier 2 accessibility tests could be run locally with the `--enable-a11y-checks` flag:

```
./mach mochitest --enable-a11y-checks somePath/someTestFile.html
```

a11y-checks are only running on Linux 18.04 x64 WebRender (opt and Shippable) builds on remote, so when you'd like to run only a11y-checks on Try, you could query `a11y-checks linux !wayland !tsan !asan !ccov !debug !devedition` for all checks (i.e. with `./mach try fuzzy --full` command). summary: Add information about good-first and good-next bugs to the triage-bugzilla document
author: tgiles@mozilla.com
text:
In order to increase the likelihood that teams triage bugs into the "good-first-bugs" and "good-next-bugs" buckets, we should add the following information to the [existing Triage for Bugzilla document](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/bug-mgmt/policies/triage-bugzilla.html):
- Under "Why Triage", we should mention the benefits of triaging bugs into good-first-bugs and good-next-bugs:
  - Helps manage backlog more effectively
  - Allows people who do not have mentorship experience an opportunity to gain that experience
  - Helps build understanding within a team (and within the larger organization) of what a "good-first-bug" is versus a "good-next-bug" versus a bug that doesn't fit into these categories
  - Allows contributors (both internal and external) to ramp up more easily by having small straightforward bugs ("good-first-bugs") and then allow them to dig deeper on follow up bugs ("good-next-bugs")
- Under some other section, or maybe "Why Triage", I don't have a strong opinion on the placement:
  - Document some heuristics on how to determine "good-first-bug" versus "good-next-bug" versus a bug that would not be a good mentored bug
    - If the bug involves adding documentation, it's probably a good first bug
    - If the bug is well-defined and is a P3/S5, it's probably a good first bug
    - If the bug involves a minor UI fix, especially if the changes are isolated to a place that isn't highly visible, it's probably a good first bug
    - If the bug is well-defined and is a P3/S3 that is a step above a good-first-bug, but not something the team is actively working on in the next 3-6 months, it's probably a good-next-bug
    - If the bug can be described as "we would like to have this", but doesn't have a firm due date, it's probably a good-next-bug (unless it's terribly complex!)
    - If a bug is a P5/S4 and appears to need a non-trivial fix, it might be a good-next-bug
